fullText: The play's power lies in its ability to transform a street corner into a stage for profound meditation on Black masculinity, survival and the elusive nature of freedom in America.
dtliExcerpt: The play's power lies in its ability to transform a street corner into a stage for profound meditation on Black masculinity, survival and the elusive nature of freedom in America.
bwwExcerpt: The magnetic Hill and Smallwood infuse Moses and Kitch with exuberant physicality; though they create distinct characters, the ineffable, mutual dependence they conjure is their chief accomplishment. Ebert applies a freewheeling buffoonery to Mister and, later, an opposite dimension of cruel menace to his other role, a policeman who under stress will undergo a dramatic conversion.
